messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 57 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Minimum Stable Cut and Treewidth

Paper Abstract: Abstract A stable or locally-optimal cut of a graph is a cut whose weight cannot be increased by changing the side of a single vertex. Equivalently, a cut is stable if all vertices have the (weighted) majority of their neighbors on the other side. Finding a stable cut is a prototypical PLS-complete problem that has been studied in the context of local search and of algorithmic game theory. In this paper we study Min Stable Cut, the problem of finding a stable cut of minimum weight, which is closely related to the Price of Anarchy of the Max Cut game. Since this problem is NP-hard, we study its complexity on graphs of low treewidth, low degree, or both. We begin by showing that the problem remains weakly NP-hard on severely restricted trees, so bounding treewidth alone cannot make it tractable. We match this hardness with a pseudo-polynomial DP algorithm solving the problem in time (Δ⋅W)O​(tw)​nO​(1)superscript⋅Δ𝑊𝑂twsuperscript𝑛𝑂1(\Delta\cdot W)^{O(\mathrm{tw})}n^{O(1)}, where twtw\mathrm{tw} is the treewidth, ΔΔ\Delta the maximum degree, and W𝑊W the maximum weight. On the other hand, bounding ΔΔ\Delta is also not enough, as the problem is NP-hard for unweighted graphs of bounded degree. We therefore parameterize Min Stable Cut by both twtw\mathrm{tw} and ΔΔ\Delta and obtain an FPT algorithm running in time 2O​(Δ​tw)​(n+log⁡W)O​(1)superscript2𝑂Δtwsuperscript𝑛𝑊𝑂12^{O(\Delta\mathrm{tw})}(n+\log W)^{O(1)}. Our main result for the weighted problem is to provide a reduction showing that both aforementioned algorithms are essentially optimal, even if we replace treewidth by pathwidth: if there exists an algorithm running in (n​W)o​(pw)superscript𝑛𝑊𝑜pw(nW)^{o(\mathrm{pw})} or 2o​(Δ​pw)​(n+log⁡W)O​(1)superscript2𝑜Δpwsuperscript𝑛𝑊𝑂12^{o(\Delta\mathrm{pw})}(n+\log W)^{O(1)}, then the ETH is false. Complementing this, we show that we can, however, obtain an FPT approximation scheme parameterized by treewidth, if we consider almost-stable solutions, that is, solutions where no single vertex can unilaterally increase the weight of its incident cut edges by more than a factor of (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon). Motivated by these mostly negative results, we consider Unweighted Min Stable Cut. Here our results already imply a much faster exact algorithm running in time ΔO​(tw)​nO​(1)superscriptΔ𝑂twsuperscript𝑛𝑂1\Delta^{O(\mathrm{tw})}n^{O(1)}. We show that this is also probably essentially optimal: an algorithm running in no​(pw)superscript𝑛𝑜pwn^{o(\mathrm{pw})} would contradict the ETH.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 57 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 57"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Grundy coloring & friends, half-graphs, bicliques",
        "Parameterized power vertex cover",
        "Local max-cut in smoothed polynomial time",
        "The lazy bureaucrat scheduling problem",
        "Inapproximability of NP-complete variants of Nash equilibrium",
        "Fast convergence to nearly optimal solutions in potential games",
        "Improved equilibria via public service advertising",
        "The many facets of upper domination",
        "Grundy distinguishes treewidth from pathwidth",
        "Parameterized (approximate) defective coloring",
        "On some tighter inapproximability results (extended abstract)",
        "Approximating pure Nash equilibrium in cut, party affiliation, and satisfiability games",
        "Improving the smoothed complexity of FLIP for max cut problems",
        "The complexity of computational problems about Nash equilibria in symmetric win-lose games",
        "Parallel algorithms with optimal speedup for bounded treewidth",
        "Time-approximation trade-offs for inapproximable problems",
        "Approximating the best Nash equilibrium in noo{}^{\\mbox{o}}(log n)(log n){}^{\\mbox{(log \\emph{n})}}-time breaks the exponential time hypothesis",
        "Approximate pure Nash equilibria in weighted congestion games: Existence, efficient computation, and structure",
        "Smoothed complexity of local max-cut and binary max-CSP",
        "Convergence and approximation in potential games",
        "New complexity results about Nash equilibria",
        "Parameterized Algorithms",
        "Inapproximability results for constrained approximate Nash equilibria",
        "(in)approximability of maximum minimal FVS",
        "Upper dominating set: Tight algorithms for pathwidth and sub-exponential approximation",
        "Nash equilibria in graphical games on trees revisited",
        "Computing good nash equilibria in graphical games",
        "Settling the complexity of local max-cut (almost) completely",
        "Parameterized Algorithms for Maximum Cut with Connectivity Constraints",
        "Smoothed analysis of local search for the maximum-cut problem",
        "The complexity of pure Nash equilibria",
        "Node-max-cut and the complexity of equilibrium in linear weighted congestion games",
        "The structure and complexity of Nash equilibria for a selfish routing game",
        "An effective dynamic programming algorithm for the minimum-cost maximal knapsack packing problem",
        "Computers and Intractability: A Guide to the Theory of NP-Completeness",
        "Nash and correlated equilibria: Some complexity considerations",
        "On strong equilibria in the max cut game",
        "The lazy bureaucrat problem with common arrivals and deadlines: Approximation and mechanism design",
        "On the complexity of constrained Nash equilibria in graphical games",
        "On the maximum weight minimal separator",
        "Hedonic games and treewidth revisited",
        "How hard is it to approximate the best Nash equilibrium?",
        "Which problems have strongly exponential complexity?",
        "An improved algorithm for parameterized edge dominating set problem",
        "How easy is local search?",
        "Structural parameters, tight bounds, and approximation for (k, r)-center",
        "Structurally parameterized d-scattered set",
        "Weighted upper edge cover: Complexity and approximability",
        "Parameterized approximation schemes using graph widths",
        "Treewidth with a quantifier alternation revisited",
        "Efficient maximal cubic graph cuts (extended abstract)",
        "Small clique detection and approximate Nash equilibria",
        "Graphical hedonic games of bounded treewidth",
        "Integer linear programs and local search for max-cut",
        "Simple local search problems that are hard to solve",
        "The computational complexity of Nash equilibria in concisely represented games",
        "Maximum minimal vertex cover parameterized by vertex cover"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 57 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Minimum Stable Cut and Treewidth, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
